text:
hey everyone this video is an addendum to 
my stuffed chicken wings recipe and in this

video I'm just going to debone the wings so 
you can just watch it with me debone it with

me so you don't have to keep rewinding to watch 
the technique I'm gonna be doing eight wings so

you got lots to come ok so just hang out with me 
and watch me debone wings so since I've got lots

to do I'm gonna just go and remove the drums from 
all of them first so do bulk actions makes it go

faster again if you're cutting this part and 
it feels stuck that means you're on the bone

you're not on the cartilage move your knife a 
little bit until it feels like it easily goes

through with no problem okay you don't want 
to ruin your knife by trying to cut through

bone and I find it easier to flip it this way 
because you can kind of see where the cartilage

is where's the other side the skin is thicker so 
it's harder to see like where the joint is oh I

hit a bone move the knife and we're good to go 
again you can be bone the whole piece it's a lot

harder but if you want to that is an option for 
you okay so again with a sharp knife go around

the joint and at this point you're trying to cut 
the ligament and the tendon that's holding the

meat onto the bone okay and then use your right 
hand to push your left hand if your left handed

and at this point you're just trying to push to 
see if your meat has been released I see that it

hasn't I see a little bit of ligament holding the 
bone onto the meat here you see that that's what

you want to go back and release so just take a 
knife and do a quick slipped and then we're free

push that down now I'm free use your finger go 
through the bone just to hold it push it through

now obviously this is not the only technique 
out there if you've got other technique you can

definitely use though this is just kind of what 
I have figured out is easiest for me there we go

just try to stay here push the 
meat down got a little bit stuck

here again push the meat down or good 
finger through the hole and pull it

off like a sock pop the joint like 
that oh the other one came out too

cut the joins cut around the joint I should say 
and again you can use a smaller knife if a big

knife like this makes you nervous but make sure 
it's sharp otherwise you're gonna have a hard

time cutting through the ligament here this one 
is always always gives me a bit of trouble this

one little little piece there okay now we're good 
finger through the hole pull it down like taking

off a sock taking off your Christmas stockings 
which no one actually wears and the last bone

is always a little harder as it becomes slippery 
because you've got less thing to hold onto now

and sometimes you'll lose that little piece of 
meat to the bone that's okay I just like take

it off and stop it back and it'll just make 
its way into the recipe somehow if there are

feathers remove them okay and I got the idea of 
doing these like just technique video and just

letting it go because when I'm searching YouTube 
to watch a particular technique I always find that

I keep having to rewind it just to watch it over 
and over again because like you know you need to

see things a couple times and I would I wish 
they would just you know show you again and

again and again and again so I figured you know 
some of you out there probably gonna want to see

this multiple times maybe like see it as you're 
doing it with me so I would just show you a lot

pop the joint pop the joint yeah 
the smaller bone is always a little

trickier because it's slippery there we go 
and peel it off don't throw away the bones

the bones are good stock material 
just save them for chicken stock

and if you're using a big knife like this 
make sure you hold the knife close to the

blade that way you have control of the knife 
it doesn't slip and I know it looks a lot

scarier than it actually is like once you 
hold it you feel like okay like I've got

this this doesn't feel wobbly it feels quite 
stable oh come on this is what happens when

I talk while I'm doing this I also find that 
some wings are harder than others almost like

the chicken is a little more mature so 
their bones and ligaments and things are

stronger and then others it's just a little 
easier to pull everything through it maybe

because when your chickens younger who knows 
this guy seems like he was a strong chicken

and I do realize that if you've got really 
fat fingers this might be a little tricky

to grab it on like this you don't need 
to put your finger through the hole it

just becomes an easy place to hand to 
hold but if you can't put your finger

through the hold and you know just do your 
best do your best for this last one let's

do a super close-up and I'll go extra 
slow just below this joint cut through

okay push the meat down with your right hand 
and so the wingtip serves as a nice handle too

so you can push it as always we got a little 
bit of stuck ligament that won't cut through

okay now we're good finger in between the two 
bones to grab if you can't do this for whatever

reason just hold it like this it's a little 
slippery er or use your pinky pull it through

pop the joint and pull it out yay beautiful and 
that's it I hope that was helpful for the full

video on what I turned these guys into make 
sure you check the link in the description

below the recipe is really delicious you 
don't want to miss it alright see you later
